newsitem.title: USA: Wheelabrator, Waste Management core units -- WMX.
newsitem.headline: Wheelabrator, Waste Management core units -- WMX.

text.p: WMX Technologies Inc Chief Financial Officer John Sanford said the company sees its Wheelabrator Technologies Inc and Waste Management International Plc affiliates as core businesses.
"Both Wheelabrator and Waste Management are core businesses for the company," Sanford said Monday at Raymond James investors conference here.

Commenting on Wall Street speculation that the Oak Brook, Ill.-based waste handling company might divest its interests in the two affiliates, Sanford said, "There is no simple way to spin them out without incurring many hundreds of millions of dollars in tax liability, and that doesn't create value for shareholders."

As for speculation by some in the investment community that WMX could somehow restructure and return to an acquisition-oriented U.S. waste industry growth strategy, Sanford said "That's virtually impossible given our size ... We are not planning on significant acquisitions."

Under pressure from major investors, including an investment group led by financier George Soros, WMX is in the midst of a restructuring that includes divesting $1.5 billion in assets, cutting 3,000 jobs and buying back 50 million shares of stock.
The company is also seeking a new chief executive since the surprise resignation February 18 of Phillip Rooney, whose ouster the Soros group and other large investors had demanded.
Sanford declined to comment Monday in an interview with Reuters on a call made February 18 by Nell Minow, a principal in Lens Fund, for his resignation. Lens is another large WMX investor.
Asked about the company's CEO search, Sanford said there is no firm timetable. But, he said, "If you look at what other companies have done, it's about a three- to six-month process."
WMX, the largest U.S. trash hauler, plans to drive $300 million out of its cost base by 1999, Sanford said. At the same time, however, he said, "I do not believe that the cost structure is bloated."
Reiterating guidance issued earlier, Sanford said WMX is targeting three to five percent annual revenue growth.
He said the company expects revenues this year of about $9.4 billion, compared with $9.2 billion in 1996. He said the company expects 1997 earnings of $1.75 per share, flat against 1996.
In 1998, he said WMX foresees earnings of $2.05 per share. After that the company expects annual profit growth "in the low double digits."
He added that WMX will strive to maintain a low single A credit rating.
